column4: hi, i just installed ubuntu desktop but i wanted to install ubuntu server (server install cd's were not available at the time), how can i transform ubuntu desktop into server? e.g. i want to take many things out of the startup list that i don't need
uninstalling xorg is not a priority
was that kubuntu or ubuntu?
ubuntu
like on gentoo, i would do "rc-update remove gdm default" to stop the welcome screen
not sure what the equivalent on ubuntu is

you can follow the instructions here on remove gnome totally - http://www.psychocats.net/ubuntu/purekde - i'd suggest removing the xorg packages too with this command  sudo aptitude remove $(aptitude search xorg | cut -c 3-30 | xargs)
ohh err, so you want to disable the GUI boot, is that all??
rather than deleting them, just taking them out of the default init runlevel should be enough
on debian/ubuntu the command is "update-rc.d" -- it can be used to disable gdm too
and i might come back asking what else i can disable, like setting console font for example
errm, not if you disable just the gdm from the runlevels no
for i in $(seq 1 6); do echo this is runlevel $i; ls -l /etc/rc$i.d/S*; done
thanks
the thing is almost all runlevels are the same on debian/ubuntu -- with the exception of 1, 6 and S
unless you change services at each runlevel - processing runlevel 2 is enough - ls -l /etc/rc2.d/S*
and to get the list of all available scripts that i can add, i would ls /etc/init.d, right?
indeed
if you are enabling and disabling services manually -- the right way to go is update-rc.d
ok, thx, and do you know where to get information about what each script is? for instance, i'm not sure what apport is
if the startup script is written right -- it should have a comment describing it's purpose at the top of the script  -- you could do    head -n 15 /etc/init.d/apport
nevermind, i'll look in packages.ubuntu.com maybe
oh, didn't know the scripts have descriptions, thanks
well, they ought to -- to make the life of administrators easy -- but thats really down to the author of the script
